data.title: ignores built-in, eslint and prettier settings
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:22:50.650Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.7.0
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
EditorConfig|Edi|0.9.4
vsc-material-theme|Equ|1.0.2
jsx|Twe|0.0.1
Handlebars|and|0.2.0
gitignore|cod|0.5.0
vscode-eslint|dba|1.2.11
vscode-babel-coloring|dza|0.0.4
prettier-vscode|esb|0.22.1
auto-rename-tag|for|0.0.14
node-module-intellisense|lei|1.4.0
vscode-JS-CSS-HTML-formatter|lon|0.2.3
peep|nwa|0.0.5
vscode-icons|rob|7.12.0

(2 theme extensions excluded)


---

I am trying out VSC to see if it's worth it to switch from WebStorm and I ran into a deal-breaking show-stopping bug which is preventing me from using it.

I have explicitly set rules for my Javascript formatting in 3 places and VSC just straight up ignores them when I save a file.

I tried using the built-in settings. They didn't work.
I tried including prettier extension. Its settings are being ignored.
I tried using eslint settings as the basis for prettier via prettier-eslint. Also being ignored.

Problem 1:
`const foo = async () => {}` becomes `const foo = async() => {}`

It "eats" the space after async.

Problem 2:
`import {foo} from 'package'` becomes `import { foo } from 'package'`

It injects spaces inside the braces. Even though I have explicitly set not to in two places.

These are my relevant settings:

.eslint (v4.3.0)
```json
"keyword-spacing": ["error", {
    "before": true,
    "after": true
}],
"arrow-spacing": ["error", {
    "before": true,
    "after": true
}],
"object-curly-spacing": ["error", "never"],
```

settings.json
```json
    "prettier.bracketSpacing": false,
    "prettier.eslintIntegration": true,
    "javascript.format.insertSpaceBeforeFunctionParenthesis": true,
    "javascript.format.insertSpaceAfterOpeningAndBeforeClosingNonemptyBraces": false,
    "javascript.format.insertSpaceAfterOpeningAndBeforeClosingNonemptyBrackets": false,
```

This means that as soon as I save a file, it eats spaces after every instance of "async (", and injects spaces inside of import braces. This causes eslint to throw errors (and show them in the editor itself) and the code won't compile in CI.

data.title: The char '(' in a array object ruin the color theme of all code bellow
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Windows 10
- Node: 7.4.0

The number values are not recognized:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4003969/28957433-2fa48264-78f2-11e7-8595-2bea24e165ea.png)

export, classname etc is also not the right color, everything bellow '(' gets the wrong colors...

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4003969/28957581-ba5232ee-78f2-11e7-9a27-f6a2aebd28d7.png)


Removing the '(' character fixes the problem 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4003969/28957490-5d38f4b2-78f2-11e7-8cb2-15f33d4a49be.png)

Removing all instances of '(' above my code fixes the colors of import, class name, etc

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4003969/28957595-d154bdc2-78f2-11e7-809b-8abe3a0eeba9.png)



Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add the following: 

```
export class Employee {
  ID: number;
  Head_ID: number;
  Full_Name: string;
  Prefix: string;
  Title: string;
  City: string;
  State: string;
  Email: string;
  Skype: string;
  Mobile_Phone: string;
  Birth_Date: string;
  Hire_Date: string;
}
```

```
const employees: Employee[] = [{
  "ID": 1,
  "Head_ID": 0,
  "Full_Name": "John Heart",
  "Prefix": "Mr.",
  "Title": "CEO",
  "City": "Los Angeles",
  "State": "California",
  "Email": "jheart@dx-email.com",
  "Skype": "jheart_DX_skype",
  "Mobile_Phone": "(213) 555-9392",
  "Birth_Date": "1964-03-16",
  "Hire_Date": "1995-01-15"
}, {
  "ID": 2,
  "Head_ID": 1,
  "Full_Name": "Samantha Bright",
  "Prefix": "Dr.",
  "Title": "COO",
  "City": "Los Angeles",
  "State": "California",
  "Email": "samanthab@dx-email.com",
  "Skype": "samanthab_DX_skype",
  "Mobile_Phone": "(213) 555-2858",
  "Birth_Date": "1966-05-02",
  "Hire_Date": "2004-05-24"
},
```

2.


Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Fast two finger scroll in integrated terminal sometimes does not execute
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:34:09.706Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
cpptools|ms-|0.12.2
csharp|ms-|1.11.0



---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open vscode
2. Open terminal
3. Type enough stuff that you can scroll up and down
4. Do a fast two finger scroll flick (has to be quick enough; essentially something like where you're trying to get back to the bottom after scrolling up a bunch)

Expected: Scrolls down fast
Actual: Nothing; actually nothing happens.  Note: It appears to be an input event queue issue.  If you do a two finger flick and it doesn't scroll, then you just move the mouse (while still in the terminal), the scroll will occur correctly implying that the events are in the queue but just not being drained.  Note also that I'm on a Surface Book (in case that matters) and that this issue does not occur in any other two finger scrolling scenarios so far implying it's not an OS issue.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: [Feature request] Auto-hide to terminal on focus lost
data.body:
Feature request to enable auto-hide terminal (or technically, the bottom window that has the terminal) feature similar to regular Visual Studio.

Bottom window has a few states it seems:
- minimized
- visible
- expanded (almost filling the main view)

This is a feature request to add a bit that indicates whether that bottom window goes back to the minimized state whenever focus is lost (clicked in some other part of vscode or something)

data.title: Provide tool tip for TreeItem

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Win10-x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use VSCode [tree-view-sample](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-extension-samples/tree/master/tree-view-sample/src)
2. Add tooltip to the initialization of the tree node via the _command_ object: 
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-extension-samples/blob/master/tree-view-sample/src/nodeDependencies.ts#L86-L93
```ts
super(label, collapsibleState);
// add code below
this.command = {
	command: 'vscode.open',
	title: 'test command',
	tooltip: 'My Tooltip.....',
	arguments: [Uri.file('some file')],
};
```
3. Observe tooltips rendering item's title instead of the tooltip value.

It seems like there is no any work around for showing a custom tooltip for a tree-view extension.

data.title: Fails to Open File in Local OneDrive Folder
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.14.2 (cb82febafda0c8c199b9201ad274e25d9a76874e, 2017-07-19T23:34:09.706Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.16257
- Extensions: 

Extension|Author (truncated)|Version
---|---|---
javadebugger|don|0.1.3
PowerShell|ms-|1.4.1
java|red|0.8.0


It appears as though vscode is unable to "see" files that are in OneDrive when the Files On-Demand feature is enabled. Repro steps below and I'm including Steps Recorder output.

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. OneDrive Settings:
  - Enable the new Files On-Demand feature (Settings tab)
  - Set option to save documents and pictures on OneDrive (Auto Save tab)
2. Attempt to open PowerShell profile file saved at `..\OneDrive\Documents\PowerShell\Microsoft.PowerShell_profile.ps1` in vscode
  - Using the command line to open the file in vscode: 
`C:\> code C:\Users\spncr\OneDrive\PowerShell\Microsoft.PowerShell_profile.ps1`
  - Using the vscode UI: Select `File > Open File...` navigate to PS profile file, select it and click OK

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

[vscode-20170803.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1199156/vscode-20170803.zip)

data.title: Can't close the markdown preview, when it's untitled and the security setting has been changed
data.body:
- Open an untitled editor and set the language mode as markdown
- Add the cat markdown from #30879
- Open preview
- Change the security setting
- Click the 'x' or cmd+w to close the preview
- No response 😱 

Debugged out of curiosity and seems like this check in `editorPart.doCloseEditor` fails: `if (group.activeEditor && group.activeEditor.matches(input)) {` because in `areHtmlInputOptionsEqual`, `left.allowSvgs !== right.allowSvgs`.

data.title: Fix some possible TSServer spawn issues
data.body:
**Bug**
A few users are seeing issues spaning the tsserver. The most common error seems to be ERRNO when spawning it

**Fix**
- Ensure we always try to set `env.PATH`
- Use `require.resolve` to check the existance of the `electronForkStart` helper before calling spawn

data.title: Add a partial filename match to "when context" in key bindings and menu context. (feature request)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: MAC OSX

I've searched for a way to do this but cannot find one. I would really love a "when" rule to include a menu or command based on a partial match or a regex match of the filename. It would solve a lot of challenges I'm facing authoring a complex extension.

Something like:

"explorer/context": [{
          "when": "resourceFilename ~= **.jpg",
          "title": "Resize Image",
          "command": "myapp.resizeImage",
          "group": "myapp-nav"
        }
]

data.title: Whitelisted SVG sources still blocked in markdown preview on Strict
data.body:

1. Ensure the markdown preview security level is set to `Strict`

data.title: task not run with integrated shell args
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Shell commands in tasks does not get run if there's a startup call linked to the integrated terminal.

shell.bat
`echo Test`

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Use these settings :
```
    "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\Windows\\system32\\cmd.exe",
    "terminal.integrated.shellArgs.windows": [
         "/k .\\shell.bat"
    ],
```
with this task :
```
"version": "2.0.0",
"tasks": [{
    "taskName": "Hello World!",
    "command": "echo Hello World!",
    "type": "shell",
    "presentation": {
      "echo": true,
      "reveal": "always",
      "focus": false,
      "panel": "shared"
    }
  }
```
2. Run task.
3. See that "Test" is printed out, but not "Hello World!"

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: JSDoc wrapping long strings not working. Possible to concatenate or have a special format for it to concatenate
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 (64-bit)

Steps to Reproduce:

```
/**
 * GrafConfig is the configuration class that is to be injected into the Graf class
 *      it does not do anything special!
 * 
 * @class GrafConfig
 * @param {Point []} points the (x,y) array of positions for the current graph
 * @param {string} xDescription the title for the x axis to be displayed
 * @param {string} yDescription the title for the y axis to be displayed
 * @param {string} title the title for the graph that will be displayed at the top
 * @param { }
 */
let GrafConfig = function (points, xDescription, yDescription, title) {}

/* this line here you can press ctrl+. after new GrafConfig */
var grafConf = new GrafConfig(graphBucket, "Years old", "daily Income", "age vs income chart");
```

1. you can copy my code from above to start, simply use the function and on the definition press ctrl+. two times to get the JSDoc information
[
![vscode jsdoc bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10443153/28941234-6287852e-7865-11e7-8b88-acd88044a76c.PNG)
](url)

my question is, if you get a really really long description can we get the wrapping to work nicer? currently it will just break it off in the middle rather then expanding out and wrap in horrible places. if you view my image where the red line is, it should concat

I think I've seen similar issues open but I haven't seen this exact problem open yet.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Can a debug adapter indicate variables with possible-side-effects/expensive?

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
Currently my Dart debugger only shows fields from objects in debugging tooltips (no properties/getters) to avoid executing user code or causing side effects (that's the behaviour of the debugger, not my adapter, though I understand why they've done it).

I believe I could get these values from the debugger by executing the getters but it could be slow/cause side effects.

Is there a way when returning objects to provide variables that require user-input to evaluate? Similar to how in Visual Studio you can expand iterators when debugging but they're not executed automatically?

I saw https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-node-debug/issues/14 which seemed like it might be related, but I didn't understand the resolution after clicking through the related cases. I also found the `expensive` flag on `Scope` but couldn't figure out if that would be useful here.

data.title: Recent files/directories suggestion from this branch on checkout
data.body:
This is a feature request.

I'm sometimes obligated to switch development contexts, which often involves a branch switch. I would normally close all the active tabs, switch branches. Then open the relevant files; usually the 'recent' files associated with checked out branch.

I'd like to have some sort of section, maybe under the scm tab on the sidebar, that lists several of the files that were open last when this branch was checked out.

I think an easy start, in terms of implementation, would be to list directories under which files have been recently commited; check the latest commits on the branch and suggest as appropriate.

Let me know if further clarification is required.

data.title: Externalized string using %phrase_key% in package.nls.json is not respected in extension contributions tab

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.14.2 (1.14.2)
- OS Version: All OS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Externalize a package.json using package.nls.json. In this case, we have a setting that uses a string. See https://github.com/forcedotcom/salesforcedx-vscode/blob/develop/packages/salesforcedx-vscode-apex/package.json#L65

```
 "configuration": {
      "type": "object",
      "title": "%configuration_title%",
      "properties": {
        "salesforcedx-vscode-apex.java.home": {
          "type": [
            "string",
            "null"
          ],
          "default": null,
          "description": "%java_home_description%"
        }
      }
    },
```

2. Open the extension view and go to the "Dependencies" tab. Notice that it is not picking up the externalized text. See screenshot below.


![screen shot 2017-08-03 at 12 10 03 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54414/28939037-cfd98e7c-7844-11e7-8c03-a0959a7601f5.png)


3. The externalized string is honored in the Setting view but **not** the Extensions view. See screenshot below.

![screen shot 2017-08-03 at 12 10 07 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54414/28939015-c0b92074-7844-11e7-87d3-a90a03b56440.png)

Set user setting: `"terminal.integrated.lineHeight": 1.5` 2. Run a command in the integrated terminal that has background coloring: `echo -e "\033[1;41m \n - OUTPUT LINE - \n \033[0m"`

data.title: Sass variables in selector breaks emmet
